text.content: Most CI tooling, however, is quite cumbersome, and for good reason â€” to allow organizations to customize their automation, regardless of their stack and setup. But for the purpose of developing a website, it can still feel like an unnecessary and frustrating diversion on the road to delivering your web project. Configuring a .yaml file, adding and removing commands, waiting minutes for each build to run, and praying to the CI gods at each one that these are the right commands. Hopelessly rerunning the same build over and over, and expecting a different result.

rich_text.plain_text: Most CI tooling, however, is quite cumbersome, and for good reason â€” to allow organizations to customize their automation, regardless of their stack and setup. But for the purpose of developing a website, it can still feel like an unnecessary and frustrating diversion on the road to delivering your web project. Configuring a .yaml file, adding and removing commands, waiting minutes for each build to run, and praying to the CI gods at each one that these are the right commands. Hopelessly rerunning the same build over and over, and expecting a different result.

text.content: For Incremental Static Regeneration, we currently server-side render those routes. We have some development in the works for caching those pages and including fallback pages, as well. When the additional functionality is added, you wonâ€™t have to make any code changes to see the benefits.

rich_text.plain_text: For Incremental Static Regeneration, we currently server-side render those routes. We have some development in the works for caching those pages and including fallback pages, as well. When the additional functionality is added, you wonâ€™t have to make any code changes to see the benefits.

text.content: Announcing one-click install Next.js Build Plugin on Netlify

rich_text.plain_text: Announcing one-click install Next.js Build Plugin on Netlify

text.content: Currently, ISR is built in to Next.js, and we serve those unbuilt pages via Netlify Functions, rendering them new every time, to avoid that caching problem. This isnâ€™t the spirit of ISR, yes, but we are strongly in favor of atomic and immutable deploys. There are better ways to approach your sites than with this type of caching.

rich_text.plain_text: Currently, ISR is built in to Next.js, and we serve those unbuilt pages via Netlify Functions, rendering them new every time, to avoid that caching problem. This isnâ€™t the spirit of ISR, yes, but we are strongly in favor of atomic and immutable deploys. There are better ways to approach your sites than with this type of caching.

rich_text.plain_text: Incremental Static Regeneration: Its Benefits and Its Flaws
